YVOA4x-BT4FTic_7L37GbA.text: I was lured here on a lazy sunday by the prospect of an "authentic" American brunch ... and i am happy to say that i was not disappointed.The menu is sufficiently american (at least you get the stuff you get in New York). So if you are craving for blueberry pancakes, this is a place to go to. More importantly, unlike in USA, they have "short stack" options for pancakes ... so even non-Americans can order a full plate of food and eat it rather than waste half of it :)I ordered a lumberjack breakfast ... 3 pancakes with maple syrup along with bacon and 2 eggs ... turned out to be a good decision ... good food and very filling.If you order a coffee, you get free unlimited refills ... the first time i have seen that in London. How cool is that !!! :)It was surprising to see that the price of the milkshakes was £4.20. Too much ... but i still ordered a banana shake. When it arrived i realized why it cost so much. It was humongous ... a huge tumbler full of the shake ... more than double the quantity you get in other places in London. I could finish only about half of it and asked them to give me the rest of it in a takeaway glass. This is where they lose a star ... i will never understand how could a glass full of shake become only 1/4th glass full in the transfer process ... pretty clumsy in my opinion.The food was reasonably cheap ... with each of the breakfast dishes at between £5 - £8, it makes for good value for money. I will surely return here.P.S: The map on the right doesn't seem to be correct. Its at the intersection of Curtain and Rivington.P.S.2: Liverpool Street station is almost as close to the Diner as Old Street.

tkDSvn1JRh31YpGphvjerQ.text: My boyfriend and I were lured here by the idea of good old American food. The food was ok, I guess. Portion sizes were a bit small. The first waitress we had was incredibly standoffish, and I guess she decided we weren't worth the bother, because she sent a replacement. and he was okay.I can't really put my finger on it, but I just did get the nice stay awhile feeling I'm used to getting from a good restaurant or bar.

opJbcKgcDhsItlrWaItOqA.text: Hmmm... very much a Hoxton in with the in crowd joint.  The waitresses are zippy and cool, the food is errr.... distinctly average and far too expensive for what it is really.  Miss the chilli, go for the hot dogs because they are a traditional diner staple despite the fact that they are made from unspeakable bits of dead animal.  Good atmosphere but the food leaves something to be desired, like food from somewhere else.

Li26gUb-hGYi4LOzFOAtcQ.text: A burger restaurant that doesn't even ask how you'd like it cooked? It then comes overdone, and overpriced - with a 50p charge if you want garlic mayo. It looks the part, but £2 for a can of Cherry Coke = no soul.

Q9pYPSQHu7Y7-R9Kr54hRA.text: As a vegetarian, the Diner wasn't my first choice of lunch venues, but my meat starved friends dragged me in on one hungover rainy Sunday afternoon.  If you're in need of a carb injection, this is the place to go.  An impressive selection of hot dogs, burgers, & chips, as well as salads, spicy bean burgers and smoked salmon & cream cheese bagels to keep the vegetarians happy.Not to mention milkshakes and all American beer.   Next time I go in I'm going to have to try the Banana bread beer...The staff were friendly enough, although I got the feeling our waitress was on the verge of quitting so she wasn't too chirpy.   Great for novelty value, helps control the urge to escape to New york, gives you a bit of America in London.  And the food ain't bad either.

EOmLXFghltcC4u3wLbSqvQ.text: I discovered The Diner on Curtain Road whilst living in student halls on nearby Pitfield Street. Whilst not particularly student friendly in terms of price it is an experience I would definitely recommend, the retro decor and read leather booths re-creating that all American eating experience (including free refill coffee!). The menu consists of everything you could ever imagine ordering at a typical American diner, from the obligatory hot dog and fries to burritos, corn dogs, chili dogs, milkshakes, and the ever-present mystery that is 'wet fries'. They also have an all day breakfast menu, serving blueberry pancakes, fried breakfast and a whole host of other dishes that probably aren't all that good for you but taste delicious. As I mentioned before it isn't cheap, which is the biggest downside, but then London is expensive, and its worth it for the experience at least once. The service isn't the best, and with the staff's non uniform policy you'd be forgiven for thinking they would be more at home working in the American Apparel store across the road, but it's fun nontheless, and situated as it is in London's pre-eminent hipster district not bad for the odd bit of celebrity spotting - we sat across from Klaxons on what must have been their day off, and Alexa Chung is a well known regular.

x_-goyblg7fvxIHzcqj8qg.text: Nice burgers, crazy staff. Grab a window seat on Curtain Road for some great people watching.

lzjJ5slQPkMsnAsb95F5Fg.text: As an American relocated to London I was so excited to find this place after craving food from home for a few months. It was expensive and not worth the money. The Philly cheese steak wasn't even really remotely close to what a cheese steak should be and the chili cheese fries were soggy. BBQ chicken burger was good, but not worth a trip back. After the meal the food sat like a lump. Pretty much what you would expect from a chain "diner" in a foreign country.

PskQzymhDSmJbPXyuZ-aEw.text: Nice, friendly place with an ideal location in Shoreditch. Prefect for late night visits, after some pub crawling. My burger was alright, but I wouldn't get the guacamole again, because didn't taste authentic to me or at least not what I'm used to getting in California. Otherwise, everything was tasty. All and all, not bad.

QR4RnGMcAXZJYWIEX-i63A.text: It looks and smells like an American diner. The menu looked familiar too, even down to the digits - except this time they're pounds, not dollars. Ouch. Yup, it's safe to say you're not in Kansas anymore. Another give away was the waitress not asking how we wanted our eggs. They came out fried. Neither of us wanted fried eggs.Still, the food tasted pretty authentic and left me feeling wistful for the East Coast. That has to be the true measure of this establishment.

-cEsX2K17LFojCwJva3Chw.text: This place is better than American diners. Everything on the menu is delicious, and when I say everything... it's because I have literally tried everything on the menu TWICE. The drinks are strong. Worth the money and try the milkshakes with some added alcohol, oh and the banana bread beer is not to be missed!

g2hxVyXAClbj2-BxlkwTRg.text: Breakfast all day and the typical American diner food. Alternative to the Breakfast Club close by, which is often too crowded.But difficult to rate. The place is nice and busy, some tables for four people are too small to sit comfortably, but there are nice tables at the window. The staff is friendly despite the buzz. Good coffee with refill for free. The banana shake was awesome, the veggie omelet disgusting. Maybe just bad luck.

UWKHHIaHsEM9uRQ0fHN1iw.text: My first eatery since I got to London... We landed in time to see Athletics at the olympic park and ended up coming here for lunch after a friend had suggested it. The 8 of us crammed into their biggest booth. So with elbows in each other faces, we started to cram burgers and hot dogs and fries into our mouths. My boyfriend had ordered some hot dog that was loaded with mayo. Even starving, that was the most disgusting thing I've ever seen and smelled.

1aIg6N9X35u-94cG-pwE8Q.text: Proper American diner. The portions are not US diner size which is a good thing. Went there for lunch on Sunday.  Highly recommend the lumberjack breakfast and eggs florentine. Service was probably the best I have had anywhere in London. I felt like everyone genuinely cared how our meal was going. Amazing!

r-PbbjkcuPjhnZe-amtwTg.text: 5-stars for the Banana/Bailey's milkshake. Well done!1-star for making me think that I was going to get to indulge in a true diner experience. Taunting me with details down to the very minute intricacies (I'm talkin' menu font, checkered wax paper, fry size and length, staff uniforms...)Cause no matter how many details you nail, eventually the food is going to arrive and speak for itself. Mine kinda just whimpered.

dFesea0XdLYift_FlORK3A.text: A true American diner in every sense of the word, this place is awesome if you want great standard junk food. There are plenty of varieties of burger, traditional meat loafs, hotdogs and all manor of drinks.  I am a sucker for milkshakes and the banana shake I had was lovely. I had a taste of Laura N's banana shake which was bolstered with a large shot of Baileys. Wow!The prices are good. For a regular burger you are looking at shifting anything from £5 - £8. The main meals are in a similar price range but top out at £9.50.You have to pay for sides so don't expect fries with your burger. Although a burger with a side will barely cost you more than a tenner. For the standard, this is definitely worth it. If you are going to add an extra dish to your burger, go for the onion rings. They are golden rings of heaven.

JFEa4U3yoKbAwn3-bwof4A.text: Great burgers, friendly service and a slightly eclectic atmosphere. Burgers were cheaply priced for this part of London and were a fairly decent size. Cheesecake was good too, if a little light on the base. Friendly service and good atmosphere  worth a visit if in need of reasonably priced food in a hurry

nJR-amRQJROSvUHF2t0CVg.text: I used to be a big fan of The Diner but recently I've felt like standards have slipped a lot. When I first visited I loved the American gimicks and really enjoyed the food. I thought the milkshakes were also something a bit special, so thick with ice cream that you could probably eat them with a knife and fork.However, on my last visit the service was terrible. Somehow the waiter managed to strike the fine balance between ignoring some tables completely and rushing others to make a choice within seconds of sitting down. When I found a hair in my burger (not on top but properly mixed in with the mince) he just shrugged it off. Fortunately the manager quickly came over to do a bit of damage control and the burger was taken off our bill but it was only when I looked at the receipt that we had been charged an extra 50p for mayonnaisse! The prices in The Diner are already pretty steep considering that it's essentially just a burger joint and by adding extra little charges like this you can't help but feel like you're being ripped off.

6zGM0-nLNdyebweFZYyTRQ.text: As full disclosure we didn't have a full meal here, but in future I definitely won't be. This place seems like a pretty standard fairly up market American diner restaurant and serves all the usual fare. We would have gotten burgers here had we not eaten them elsewhere beforehand. We all got good-sized milkshakes which were quite enjoyable. The fries were passable but the mayonnaise that we had to request almost tasted off. The mac and cheese seemed to be 95% cheese, with no actual flavour or texture. Just endless melted samey cheese. The cheesy fries seemed to have exactly the same cheesemagedon on top as the mac and cheese. The corn on the cob was extremely salty and the lack of any prongs to eat it with made it messy and inconvenient. This stuff seems hard to get wrong but that's somehow what happened.   The music is varied and interesting and the desserts look pretty decent, but from what we experienced, the rest of the food is mediocre. The presence of a jug of tap water with no actual glasses to drink from sums up The Diner pretty well: promises much but fails on delivery.

vQlaqAygHLwgNrK8XHZCyg.text: I tried their Philly Cheesesteak on a recent visit and am happy to report that I thought it was quite delicious and a pretty good version. Yum!

gFhx5AFocHYNWrC4tltPyw.text: This is not a true American diner. Have any of you actually been to America, or did you just watch Animal House and go from there? The Diner is a fine place to eat, but with none of the size, brevity, or indeed at times service of your average diner. Or, indeed, the price points - as Glen B. mentioned (are you actually from America?). He's wrong too, sadly - The Diner is a damn sight cleaner, especially food wise, than any diner, and the burgers feel less like they're going to cause your kidneys to explode. The servers have all the enthusiasm of Lurch out of the Addams Family, and can at times just forget about you. It's possible they were hired for their looks - who knows - but they fail to provide the (usually) quick and helpful service of a good diner. In fact, the place is predominantly black and red. Most diners are lighter colours. What the bloody hell are you all talking about? In summary, the food's generally good, a little overpriced, but this is about as much like a diner as I am like an Alsatian.

gQJGxa23ooI3uOuTJ5TRQw.text: I like that it is hip and open late. I did find my vanilla milkshake, however, decidedly mediocre. Sadness. I'll probably return at some point anyway and try the food.

Xlz-A2YEK-yPEO2NIBoXRw.text: This place saved my need for carbohydrates after a night out. First of all, I loved the decor, there is nothing more cool than a diner style restaurant, that has a modern hip twist to it. Me and my mates where looking for a place where we could find some comfort food. After a night out, when someone suggested this spot, we thought it was the best occasion to get some nice hearty burgers and chips! So we all went there and enjoyed the so needed burger with fries. It was quite good, I recommend you ask for some Dijon mustard and dip their lovely chips in this spicy yet soft mustard. For me this place is just a cool spot to go with friends, have a beer to ease of a nigh out and enjoy a good burger, and of course enjoy the much healing power of fries.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

uNN_y9XG8VvLS3x5DgN-Og.text: Hmmm. I was so excited to go here, i love anything American. The menu totally got me excited, i went for some chili fries (hello how Saved By The Bell) and a Cobb salad.  Although very American, i wasn't overly impressed with the quality of the food. I went back the other day, i craved a milkshake and I've heard they're the best. It was okay, not going to lie i drank it so fast i was nearly sick. I particularly love this location, situated in the trendy shoreditch, you're a stones throw away from amazing bars and an amazing vibe. P.s. the girls are hot. So you know, it's worth a visit.

LCB3DrJVJoBh7yIau4jtqA.text: I could sum up this place in two words and feel satisfied that is was enough. WET FRIES. I am obsessed with gravy and would (almost literally) bathe in the stuff if i could. To find a place that serves you chips swimming in the liquid wonderment is going to have a pretty damn special place in my heart. Great novelty layout, your food arrives in a basket (like in the movies - wow), and the staff, although a little too cool for school, are really accommodating. We once had a surprise dinner for a friend in here and they sorted out a cake for us, and whipped in out right on cue. Stuff yourself senseless on hot dogs and fries and milkshakes and then trot off to a drive in movie, wait i mean to a local pub - this ain't the movies!

Y4bzr2mkwK5RV1Dx8UNFVA.text: Two words: HARD SHAKES! Ice cream is awesome, alcohol is awesome, together they are EPIC. Before The Diner, I didn't know alcoholic milkshakes even existed. Talk about fun getting buzzed... Their regular milkshakes are also good. Also, this was the ONLY place that had non-gross hot dogs. Not like I'm in constant need of encased meat, but British sausages are gross and mushy. The Diner has delish hot dogs that aren't a sad tube of mush. For those two reasons, I find The Diner worthy of four stars.

YdZfbhjAq0HuLJ-FHEjyUg.text: I remember coming here with some friends after many many drinks at the old blue last.  We were starved to death and when our burgers arrived, none of spoke as we devoured our burgers.  At the time, we all agreed that these were the best burgers we had ever had in our lives.  Having returned there recently, this time slightly more sober, I am afraid that I will have to retract that comment.  The burgers and chili fries are great, but I cannot describe them as the best ever anymore.  I do love how they come in little red baskets, and if you pretend hard enough and ignore the English accents around you,  you might be able to imagine that you are indeed in a west-coast American diner.  Order the burgers, chili fries and a Mexican beer for the perfect experience.

oPi7LL4b7noPHqOcu52Nzw.text: The Diner's "milkshakes brings all the boys to the yard, and they're like it's better than yours, damn right it's better than yours, I can teach you, but I have to charge." So amazing never disappointed by The Diner's shakes. And the venue is hip and requires you to scream and shout over the music but it's all in good fun!

9LZ7-a_jD3rB6kwMX4rZEg.text: I'm being generous when I say that my last meal at the Diner was close to total junk.I have lived in the area for 12 years, and have eaten at the Diner several times over that period. I can say unreservedly that you should avoid eating here. The food is DREADFUL and gives UK cuisine a bad name - even when we're trying to copy simple American diner food, we can't get it right. Go eat at any number of greasy spoons nearby - Franco's on Rivington Street springs to mind - and you'll get MUCH better food, for a fraction of the price. The Diner charges criminal prices for junk. Not good junk, cheap nasty junk. We had to send our "Diner Fries" back as they were inedible. My partner's burger was awful, as was my halloumi burger. Seriously, guys. Step up your game.

E_7uA7QfDDgSh8iDKTxWBg.text: I am definitely a fan of this place.  This fit the picture in my mind of what an American diner is: comfortable booths, plenty of options and large servings.  I had a great brunch.It was a chilly afternoon when we arrived and there was a short line for a table and we were told we would have a 20-minute wait.  It wasn't too bad though - when the door was closed, were were out of the cold and we were kept up to date with when tables were freeing up.  It's a plus for this place that they pay attention to the line, but at the same time not hurrying up people to finish their meal.I had a short stack of pancakes and sides of bacon and hash browns.  Those hash browns!  Ah - they were massive and had the perfect hash brown crunch (though, I note, a little oily - but that's part of the experience).  I got a filter coffee too, and could have endless refills.  On such a cold day, it was nice just to be holding the hot cup of coffee.I would come here again and try some more of the menu.

37Ji4FypAMnV1iXqMbNWLQ.text: One word: yum. You've probably already heard about this place so there's not much else I can say but DEFINITELY try the pancakes and literally any one of their burgers. Also their milkshakes are the perfect Sunday evening pick-me-up. And finally, you can order from them on Deliveroo! Enjoy peeps - I might go back there this weekend so I may try new stuff and write about that. Watch this space!

rnEbphR1dW9V0K92wG5dOg.text: Were they busy, yes. Should it ever take a restaurant 15 minutes to have the bar "make" me a tap water, no. Staff is nice but this place could do with a fair bit of management. Food was hit or miss, cheese fries couldn't hit the broad side of a barn. Overpriced and overwrought.

KYTDSa-FFP0jOoY4c3MN6w.text: Im Amurrrican. I have an inherent understanding of what a diner should be. And this as close as I've found so far. Maybe the other branches are better but this one was just ok.Came with my trusty hangover to test out their diner dishing skills. Ordered a short stack o pancakes and some Amurrican bacon. Yes the bacon was smoked and streaky but not quite right. And the syrup was maple maybe? It too didn't taste quite right. But it was the right amount of sugar, fat and carbs to perk me up for the rest of my Sunday. Staff was friendly but barely attentive. We had to flag them down finally even when they had already passed us like five times.  I shall come back again and try a lunch item. Maybe my rating will improve.

kSGllgdEUMv7RPAlRZT-_Q.text: It's nice and a reasonable price but didn't blow me away.I had a Mexican breakast with baked eggs which was tasty but lacking a bit of spiciness!I also had a bloody mary with a bacon topping which was interesting! Our waiter was a bit odd and a bit over friendly.Would probably choose breakfast club over here!

WJszkr5aoeOV8WEkq3Du8Q.text: Food tasted fine. Haloumi burger and the shakes were lovely. But far too stodgy, and arrived slightly cold. Service a little too contrived.

CdgaRdsyTpcEw2NdsFpHAQ.text: Great friendly service, a Tuesday evening so no problem getting a table. More Amedican beers like the goose island would make this place even better.

PZN6ZuOvvGx1JzQIWU_7GA.text: Does what it says on the menu, and it has all the right things (for a diner) on the menu. Burgers, steak sandwich were what we chose, impressively the burger was cooked as requested medium rare, and excellent quality. Service was also excellent although we were there at a busy time. Seating is diner style pack'em in, tomato ketchup, chilli sauce and (american) mustard on the table, nobody got hurried out. Lots of stuff to choose from, also for veggies, the eggs florentine looked very appealing. Don't expect change from £10 a head especially if you have drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

wEk3GvKuqXjlP_7t8pxS0A.text: The Hungry Man breakfast was a bit too close to your regular British fry-up. I was hoping for some of that crisp bacon you only get in the US... but apparently you can only get it in the US.

K7jpTwd6q0TjsCelK-so6w.text: Blueberry pancakes, blueberry pancakes, blueberry pancakes...oh and maple syrupI love The Diner although typically I end up at the one in Angel as that is where my usual brunch buddy lives. This time, however, I managed to drag some of my old housemates out for bite of good ol American breakfast.Despite a line out the door, we were seated within 10 minutes in a snug booth that screams out "personal space? what type of quaint British notion is that?" that is just typical of the American dash-in dash-out eating experience. That being said, while you do get close to your fellow diners (I leaned back and accidently knocked into the girl behind me), you can stay at The Diner as long as you want without being rushed (and getting free refills on coffee - typical diner experience). I always for for brunch, so will only speak to that part of the menu. The blueberry pancakes are fantastic. Light fluffy circles of dough with a very generous portion of fresh blueberries is a great meal to start your day feeling at least somewhat healthy. The side of oily spicy chorizo perhaps negated any such effects but screw it, I love me some chorizo.One down side is that our "fresh" orange juice tasted more like Sunny D that any sort of actual juice. In addition, the coffee is a bit weak but luckily you can grab a good strong espresso next door at The Bean which makes everything better.One of our party's orders was misplaced (exactly how this happens I don't know) but they quickly made it again and didn't charge us for it so all is forgiven.Overall, love the food, liked the service, hated the coffee, but I'll be back with an espresso in hand.

zLqMBNUoEQaLuDuz-_SO2g.text: Went here on the recommendation of a friend and I was not disappointed! After a long morning of playing tourist (and I am a bad tourist because I would rather sit in pubs than make my way around museums!) I parked my tired limbs and ordered the pancakes. Ave Maria and all the saints, they were good. It could be that I haven't eaten gluten for a year (hey, a gluten allergy doesn't count on vacation, right?) but these fluffy disks of comfort food hit the spot. I felt a little weird ordering such a typical American dish while abroad but, honestly, if I ate another fry up death would have come quickly :)

cvY4O9cuLYvo4sY1s8Bv9A.text: Nothing exciting ended up here by default ... Wanted to go to meat liquor but the line was way to long to wait in , then I wanted to try Pit cue but it was closed for the night so in frustration and hunger we stopped here.. Nothing special and won't go out of my way to come here again... Meat liquor is a million times better even GBK does a better burger... Don't get me wrong the food is edible just nothing special to write home about and I feel £4 for a milkshake is  over priced considering a milkshake in America is only 4 dollars

kZTqUCg3LuYjvD6pXKOKBQ.text: We only went here because it was 30 feet from our front door, and we were with non-yelpers. Don't let it's semi-busyness fool you, this place basically sucks. The fries look great (thin) but are undercooked mush (why is this a pandemic) and had no taste. Their pathetic "large" milkshake could easily all fit in the small glass, but they insist on bringing the practically empty steel container just to rub it in. My burger was NOT dry (second star). Every ketchup bottle within a grenade's radius was empty and the our waitress, once hailed, left the three other water glasses empty after she filled mine. Knock yourself out doubter.

S1wgTko3Kx7mh-f9uEFKPg.text: I really would love to give this place 4 stars, since I'm an ex-pat and it does have reasonably good food and is right around the corner, but I just can't. First problem, the service wasn't that good. I could have hoped for an older fatter lady with her hair up in a bun supported by a pen she used to take down my order, but it was not to be... tragically hip youngsters with no interest in their job.I ordered a hamburger with grilled onions chilli cheese fries and a cherry coke. The bread was good, but the meat tasted like one of those cheap frozen patties that aren't even thawed before being thrown out onto the grill. The tomato wasn't fresh it was a little greasy overall. The fries were good, but also a little bit too greasy. Still, I left with a good feeling and will go back there, so it's more like a 3.5. If they had better service I'd feel better about giving it a 4.

Ht8PCAsRY27KtjwCRb-lZg.text: Fun place. Lousy food.My cheeseburger  tasted like a cardboard. The corn beef hash I persuaded my friend to have, tasted like it came out of a can. On top of that, this muck took ages to come. This was the kind of dreadful British version of American food you used to get in London in the 70s. I thought we'd moved on.It's not hard to cook a good burger...especially when burgers are supposed to be the speciality of the restaurant, this was totally unacceptable.

jgmxq-HPnPVFj5BOTsR-YQ.text: It's like this:- the service is terrible. Your waitress will be dressed head to toe in American Apparel (it is conveniently across the road) and will alternately ignore you and reply to anything you say in a bored monotone. She will also leave you waiting anywhere between 15 minutes and half an hour to a) order, b) receive your drinks, c) pay your bill.- the food, for what it is, is expensive. It's generally ok taste-wise but a full-on breakfast for two people will cost you about 20 quid. After all a can of coke costs £2.These two, enormous, problems aside I still kind of like it! It's one of the only places that I can loiter, probably due to the bad service, for hours over once slice of apple pie and a coffee and not be bothered by a waitress trying to shoo me onwards. In fact my best stretch has been somewhere near 4 hours which I have to say wins it back some points in my book.

sZaWv87elg6RS2Nvn7zZ6Q.text: We stumbled upon this place whilst wandering around Shoreditch. The lightening bolt on the neon sign must've lured me in!I got super excited at the prospect of finding a good American diner in London. When I opened the menu, I was totally overwhelmed! Corndogs, chili cheese fries, milkshakes, oh my! What I really wanted was a sampler platter so I could try all of it. I randomly ended up with the huevos rancheros. And can I just say that was some of the best guacomole I've had in a long time?? Totally unexpected! My partner got a lumberjack breakfast. OMGSOGOOD. Bacon, eggs, and pancakes served with real maple syrup! It was scrumptious. It harkened us back to our diner days in Chicago. The prices were pretty good, a tad on the expensive side which took away from a real diner feel, but hey what can you do.  The interior was great and even made me a little homesick! Overall, it was a pretty cool place, but the trek to Shoreditch (from Richmond) probably means it can't be a regular thing.

_zfyiNuPq9t9BDTPcEI2fw.text: American diner joint serving good burgers and shakes.Good solid place but the two highlights that will blow you away are:Philly cheese burger (slices of great steak with lots of lovely sauce and cheese and onions)Snickers milkshake (chocolate Icecream shake with peanut butter, Nutella, choc chips and maple syrup - absolutely amazing, best shake in London Town - and I would know.... Burp...)

_j0S8h1rvSKcKo5WkFZeHQ.text: Not my first visit to the Diner but my first visit to this Diner. The Vegan options are quite limited, but the options they have are very tasty! Unfortunately they were out of quite a few things (eg. fresh orange juice and one of the ingredients for a cocktail my friend wanted) but we ended up deciding on some stuff they did have.Staff are all very friendly but sadly the waiting time was quite long - we sat down at 7.15ish and didn't get our food until almost 8pm... Which meant I was very late for a gig I was supposed to go to at 8pm!Food wise it was all delicious... The vegan Taco Bowl was great but perhaps Sligtky overpriced at £9... Similarly to the "mashed avocado" on the breakfast section of the menu is really just glorified guacamole. And as much I love avocado/guacamole, not sure that dish was really worth £4ish (can't remember exact price).I would go back in the future but as long as I had plenty of time to spare!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Vegan options: Vegan Taco Salad Bowl, sweet potato fries & smashed avocado! Very colourful and very delicious.

rqItHnvIiXIEz2HMi9Z4Dw.text: Delicious as usual, I had the sweet potato fries and Mac and cheese which I combined into the ultimate meal of awesomeness. Servers were lovely and cheery.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

tbzHIpUCqYp-IoAAm9eNjw.text: "OH I LOVE DINERS.""OH, diners are an American thing?" "Yes." --I'll likely only come for dessert (if I were to return at all). The food is fairly mediocre, but it's a safe bet if you just need a quick meal (we did). The burgers are OK, my "english muffin with eggs" was exactly that with nary a glance of anything more exciting or intriguing. The 2-top booth we sat in was so small our knees bumped and we were balancing things on top of each other to make room at the table. But diner dessert? Well you know, they do it well. Simple and huge portions. Go for that. Pro-tip get the "peanut butter and blueberry" sundae minus the blueberry and plus the chocolate. Service was quite good, a friendly bunch. 27 quid fo 2, a bit overpriced for "diner food" but I'd pay double for that dessert. Ok I wouldn't, but I'd eat two.

DfGFOTM4LgJhPEDR45PAjw.text: We decided to check out what shoreditch area has to offer, and looks like quite a lot, we ended up in this place - craving for brunch, but the burgers were really appealing... See we took them.The place really feels like a diner and it was all pretty hip with a big menu full of goodies, and great music!I had a Mexican burger (with chili con carne and jalapeño) and my friend had the Diablo if I remember correctly. As she doesn't like her food too spicy I was lucky to get her spicy mayo which was super tasty. The food arrived rather quick and the portion is just the right size. As extras we had garlic butter fries which were ok, until we found out we have a little puddle of garlic butter at the bottom, and then it was tasty.The sweet potato fries however are pretty good. I'm not sure if I liked my burger or if I was super hungry, but there was something missing in it for sure, just can't tell what it is exactly. What I didn't like is the service- the waitress came to our table to give us menus first, which is fine, and then again to ask if we're ready... We asked for a little more time, and she just kept coming every minute to ask if we're ready- I'll call you when I am! It was ok - but then she did it again when I was eating. First time to see if everything cool, but then she came around asking "do you need anything else?" About 4 or 5 times while eating and afterwards. If this is your way of making people go or order more - it's wrong. And it's annoying. I'd give this place 4 stars if it wasn't for that annoying waitress.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Mexican burger

rktP4TBul0uBXPc6EP5ESg.text: Had lunch here cuz my school is just 1min walk from here. Quite good overall. I ordered the Hawaiian Burger with extra mushroom(don't really like the mushroom:()We had fries as well and they were ok not brilliant but fine. The corn dog is good:)

xV6Tu4SdWzhg5AzDPWIHrg.text: Don't order bacon pancakes, they put too much Vinigear in them. Sauce is not good too.

VsLe4wNKCltrV9mcTJNJyQ.text: Smack in the heart of Shoreditch, great place for a burger and chilli cheese fries if you can't get into the Blues Kitchen two doors up the street. Their shakes are brilliant (especially the ones that are spiked). The Diablo is super tasty. I had the cheese fries with burger gravy which went down well (and were a super calorie bomb to boot ;-). Wash it down with some cold beer, and you're either laying the foundations for a great night out drinking in East London, or creating sufficient lining to protect you from a night of excesses. It's not haute cuisine; it's not Hawksmoor; it's not Meat Mission or Meat Liquor. But it exists, it's nice, it's fun, cosy, and a great stop gap.

ks5iiHqKTxYw73eH0zglJQ.text: The Diner Caesar salad was absolutely atrocious. Some of the ingredients listed were missing (anchovies) and the croutons were diced dry burger buns. I felt like I had been given leftovers. The avocado consisted of 4 tiny cubes of avocado, would have been the same to not add any avocado at all! And for £10, what an absolute ripoff. Shame on this business for allowing itself to scam customers like that.

7FMDjuPbZMFncgUEKS5jgQ.text: Disclaimer: Most other locations of The Diner are poor at best (I'm looking at you Spitalfields) but the breakfast at Curtain Road is the most consistently fantastic weekend treat in the neighbourhood. Service is always super nice, brisk and friendly, they have TATER TOTS and even though I'm not a fan of pancakes I am a fan of these pancakes. I don't know what magician works in this kitchen but please clone him or her and distribute to your other locations. Curtain Road 4ever.

0X4llvWObU8ub1ZWyQtKBw.text: I came here for lunch. I ordered a Philly cheese steak and the misses order a chicken burger.Burger was great but the Philly cheese steak was not to good, I'm not from America but the misses is and she said it not what it should of been.We also ordered chilly cheese fires and she said they were "ok"Ordered beer from America. Was a bit over priced but o well.

wW-CP9Gbvx7s2WSp8guOiw.text: Though my friend (also American, but living in London full time) and I waited about 45 minutes on a Thursday evening to eat at The Diner in Shoreditch, I have to admit it was worth it. The place is clean, the vibe is chill, and the food is really good. My friend and I each had one of the many burgers plus a side of the Chili Fries and the Onion Rings...and some wine, too, of course. It was a fun meal and I would totally go back, if only I lived in London. P.S. Ask your server what "American" sauce is...too funny.

dRmpEhQ6-lA2c4OubNM6Eg.text: This is the 3rd Diner location I have been to and the food was just as good as the others! It's nice to know that there is a chain that guarantees good food no matter which one you step into. The only problem I have is that they stopped serving banana bread beer... WHY OH WHY?!?!?! Please bring it back!!!!!The atmosphere was fun, the California burger cooked to perfection, and the chilli cheese fries as delicious as usual. Perfect meal before a booze filled night. Yum, yum yummy!

kujcfACYy4AOi5oq8mMKXg.text: After attending Yelp's Whiskey tasting event, I was feeling optimistic that this area could provide me with some good food afterward. With a crew of fellow Yelpers with me, we headed to The Diner for some grub.I could probably moan on for a fairly long time about our experience here, but in short, I had the worst breakfast burrito that you could possibly imagine (imagine a soggy, floppy flour tortilla filled with poorly scrambled egg, and some cheap and nasty chorizo) accompanied by a dribble of dead looking re-fried beans and another dribble of grey guacamole.The failures did not end there. We ordered a pitcher of Whiskey Sours for the table, only to find out that our £32 only provided us with 4 1/2 full small tumblers of cocktail. So that's £16 a glass, then, is? The menu price per glass did not even cost as much as the pitcher. When I mentioned this to our waitress, she treated us with a non-caring attitude and replied with a surly "That's because you haven't filled your glasses with ice; do you want to speak to the manager then?". So... The ice is the important aspect in a cocktail then?!? I was quite taken aback with the attitude and this was apparent when we were handed the bill - the old 12.5% service charge added to the bill! The scourge of good service in London!To be fair to the establishment, when the manager did materialize and after a lengthy conversation, he agreed to only charge us £15 for the picture of ice! He was a nice chap, although it took a lot of wrangling to get to this resolution.Needless to say, I will not be returning to the diner in a hurry. Which is a real shame because I was hoping for some real American food and service. Well... If you are expecting that go elsewhere.

j4ECD691q0seT9TyRUfTxQ.text: Hmmph!  The Diner had me full of anticipation for American authenticity.  But I was to be cruelly disappointed!Typical diner decor.  Defensive waitress.  Mediocre food.  My halloumi burger barely filled its bap.  Long on bread, short on filling.  My fat fries were dry and bland.  I tried to get the waitress's attention to get some mayo to no avail.One pitcher of Whisky Sours only half filled four small tumblers.  When we pointed this out to the waitress she was apathetic and defensive.  The manager shrugged his shoulders but eventually gave us a discount.For the service and standard of food this place is way overpriced!  I won't be going again.  Boo!  Hiss!

HA6TK3Bx7_UPiBeJYIb0xw.text: I don't want to like The Diner, but I do. Their eggs beni are delish and they serve proper American root beer. Granted it tastes like Pepto Bismol but, what ever floats your boat!When you are craving brunch and you're in Old Street you head over to The Breakfast Club Hoxton. You get there and then you see the queue coming out the door. You're hangover seems to get worse as you panic... 'Think, think!' to tell your brain, 'there must be somewhere close by that can fix this sore head...' Then you remember The Diner. You hopes and spirits rise as you walk 5 minutes to the beacon of hope.The diner is great - expensive and staffed by up-themselves hipsters, but still great. Serving up a nice selection of American inspired food, you can slide you bum into one of their booths and receive a tasty meal. It's an open kitchen so you can see them grilling up your breakfast which I quite like, they also serve 'hard-shakes' so if you're feeling like a hair of the dog, you can add a kick to your meal. They also do tasty bloody marys, you'll just have to hand over 7 of your hard earned pounds to slurp away at one.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Root beer joy!
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

KSY2jbhc84FPmW35Q2Lr9w.text: I arrived late, apologetically so, but having been waved with dispassion to the corner group of be-Christmas-jumpered rowdy cats in the back, next to the rows upon rows of other brunching groups in santa hats and others with crackers on the table,  you'd a thunk I'd stood up my server not missed the first round of Bloody Marys (they went down well as they were in fact rather good- my choice every time over a 'hard shake').My group, of caterwauling cats at the back, were only in festive spirits, not misbehaved. Of course, it was only me who brought to the table complications. Other wise what would I write about? I know I can be a testing diner for any server, however my poor pencil moustachioed man-server was merely run off his feet not mercurially presenting a lack of personality. For this he had plenty. So for brunch as usual, all I wanted was breakfast with a poached egg as soft as my Christmas temperament after watching 'Miracle on 34th St'. As the first eggs were laid on plates around the table, I noticed what seemed to play in slow-mo, the tension of the knives around the table plunge into powdery hard edged yolks and soldiers which were submitted to the reverb boing into an overdone egg, I panicked. Being the last to order I sprang out of my tables festive formation and alerted my sassy disinterested server of my need for a very runny egg. My poached order on fried rye and tomatoes arrived and was continuing to coddle in an iron pan, so it was with great urgency that I needed to get started. It came not quite hard boiled, thank god. Yet it wasn't soft nor cascading with runny yellowness. My h'angry party weren't as bothered about a soft egg as I am, but please breakfast chefs, get those eggy bad boys out of the hot water as soon as you say 1 Mississippi!! By the time it's sat under the serving hatch there'll be less chance for eggy disappointment. It was dangerously hardening by the second. But I needed Mustard. English Mustard. I requested Coleman's of course, Maille I'd have happily gone with, but the server replied "There's Mustard on the table", but I wanted English not vinegary weak American, ironically French's. The Diner brand's discourse was that, "Hey This is Shoreditch, someone wants Soy Milk, the next person wants Almond, one guy wants Stevia, the next Agave, which we do have, would you like that"...  "Oh we've run out" was the recoil, "So where, does it end". I would have preferred being creatively lied to, simply "we've run out" would've been better, but the reasons for no English mustard were weak when paying nearly £20 for the novelty of a shabby New York diner style breakfast, for that much I want you to crown me with condiments. I've been to better burger vans on the coast with a better selection of sauces than here. I'm not a Christmas Killjoy, only I just don't get how the theme of a New York diner is so popularly impressive. To me, the epitome of a New York diner is being served by some sour-faced Betty near or over retirement, with well kept nails, hair complete with a hairnet and doily, serving up greasy food; stack em up pancakes, over easy eggs and terrible drip coffee, (The Diner's coffee was actually acceptable and with the US tradition of free refills being available, I'm surprised we weren't all rocking in our seats with how much caffeine we had coursing round the table), but why on earth would you want to recreate the model of a drab American diner experience, I don't understand. Bloody Shoreditch!To make it more of a novelty, kitsch uniforms at The Diner would be cool. (Like the City Cafe in Edinburgh) It is a little embarrassing being less chic than the server, I was wearing a Christmas Jumper though.

VOkPpwpjtSPeOVvfvDJQ2g.text: The Diner delivers when it comes to American-style pancakes, the choice of fries, good music and even some of its fancier burgers, but it's less impressive when it comes to milkshakes or when we were there, an accurate beer list.Seeking to maximise the moment, I opted for two dishes one after the other: an 'original' basic burger, milkshake and when those and a smattering of sweet potato fries left more room than anticipated after a long cycle across London, a high stack of 5 pancakes.The 'Original' burger was okay if a little uninspired. It tasted more well-done than medium, and the sauces could have been better. The milkshake was also slightly disappointing. Okay, but not as cold or ice-creamy as those from Byron, whom I consider to lead the milkshake stakes in London at present. My dining companion's 'Arch' burger on the other hand, packing pulled pork and montery jack was really good.So on it was to the high stack of pancakes. And they were impressive, certainly the biggest such stack I've seen in London. Five, inch-thick pancakes piled high, dusted with icing sugar and with an apparently bottomless (in that the waitress was happy to bring more at no extra charge) small bowl of maple syrup. I tucked in, and was captivated at the first bite. Alas though a stack this high was never going to be conquered by a few bites and eventually I had to concede defeat, about 20% short of the finishing line. Still, they rate as among the best and most genuine American-style pancakes I've had in London.The beer list was a let-down: notable on paper, disappointing in that they had less than half of the beers actually in stock. Apparently this was because they were refreshing their menu, but a couple of weeks on, and the online menu now seems to be 90% identical to the one when we were there. Hmmm.Other pluses were the decent music (various mixes of pop and rock classics) and quick, friendly service. The Diner exceeded my expectations, particularly for its pancakes and Arch burger. I declare myself a fan.

repkkbXHq__Ko1U74eVCaA.text: Sorry London. I wish I could say this place was OK but I'd be lying. The server was extremely nice and deserves a four star. This is just an honest review of the food. I ordered chili cheese fries that arrived with the cheese already somewhat congealed and the conservative dressing of chili randomly had an oversized hunk of steak in it. I mean there's no straight rule to making chili but it was just kind of random and extremely oversized. The main gripe with the  chili cheese fries were: when I order chili cheese fries I want to feel guilty as hell after eating it. In no part of my experience do I want the delicious melty cheese to have a party without me!I ordered a fried chicken taco salad which came as a grilled chicken taco salad ( all good, I'm not one to send food back unless its disgusting ). The grilled chicken had some grill marks but overall was suspiciously wet for being "grilled". Considering all the food options in Shoreditch, I won't be going back here.

VNz_FJZl3sR-O3swAymycw.text: I always over-order and under finish here, and tumble out into the night with a food baby, slightly miffed that I couldn't finish all of my food. Which is probably for the best - I've heard diabetes isn't all that fun.The staff are fun, the people watching is good and the prices are pretty reasonable  - 15 pounds each for a dinner we couldn't finish, including service. Mmm, chocolate-peanut-butter shake, onion rings, cheese fries, mac n' cheese...I'll be back. But next time I'll skip the shake and only order a side of mac n' cheese. Here's hoping I remember.
